Garreth Browne Wachsman
Hi @akibalogh, we received another inbound request today this time from Cointelegraph (UMVs: 11.2M).

The journalist is looking for commentary on BTC halving prices:
- What Bitcoin halving will mean for the wider market and
- How this might affect the mining side of things

Would this be something you'd be interested in providing commentary on? If so, if you wouldn't mind providing a couple of lines on each of the above we'll be happy to review and assist. Cointelegraph is a major T1 outlet so this would be a great opportunity to get you placed as an industry expert on this topic. Thanks, Garreth üëç
AB
11:54
Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
Definitely! CoinTelegraph is a great source for us (probably Tier 1), since they've been writing about BTC, ordinals, etc. for years. And they don't have the ideological constraints of Bitcoin Magazine.

- Halving means that miners are pushed to find other ways to earn yield - through investing their BTC assets
- Historically, miners could rely on BTC price appreciation. But for most miners, they will be unable to be profitable at standard electricity rates anymore
- Typically miners were profitable above 12 cents per kwh. But now, anything above 6-8 cents per kwh will be unprofitable
- Miners are scrambling to find additional sources of yield, incl CeFi and DeFi vehicles
- We believe that DeFi is safer than CeFi, due to its transparency and since it doesn't rely on intermediaries who could themselves fail
- Miners are reluctant to swap their BTC for other tokens that could lose value
- dlcBTC is the only wrapped Bitcoin solution that lets miners self-custody their BTC while earning DeFi yields on it
üëç

10:21
Garreth Browne Wachsman
Hi @akibalogh, I hope you are well.

We received another inbound request from a journalist at Decrypt (UMVs: 2.7M) who is also looking for commentary on the BTC halving. They're interested in hearing whether the halving will be favourable for miners and why? How miners will be impacted by the halving and what they should they do to prepare.

If you'd be interested in contributing to this piece, to save time we reworked some of the commentary you shared with us yesterday. Please review when you can and let us know if you'd like any changes or amendments made. As always, any questions please let us know üëç

"With Bitcoin halving, miners are compelled to seek alternative avenues for generating yield from their BTC assets. Previously reliant on BTC price appreciation, many miners now find it unfeasible to remain profitable at current electricity rates, with profitability typically above 12 cents per kWh but now dropping to above 6-8 cents per kWh.

As a result, miners are exploring additional yield sources, including CeFi and DeFi options. DeFi, in particular, stands out for its transparency and independence from intermediaries, reducing counterparty risks. Miners, wary of potential token devaluation, hesitate to exchange their BTC holdings.

To prepare, miners should explore alternative solutions. For example, dlcBTC (Discreet Log Contract Bitcoin) emerges as a premier wrapped Bitcoin option, allowing miners to maintain self-custody of their BTC while capitalizing on DeFi yields."

Hi @akibalogh, the journalist at Cointelegraph has asked a follow up to the above opportunity. They want to know,

"What will the Bitcoin halving mean for Ethereum (and by extension, the wider market)?"

05:20
In reply to this message
Brilliant, thank you for sharing!
AB
07:20
Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
The halving will lead to a supply shock, as supply of BTC mined drops while demand continues to grow (due to BTC ETFs, demand for blockspace due to Ordinals and other assets, and "Building on Bitcoin" projects such as L2s). This is expected to sharply increase BTC price.

Also, Microstrategy has been cornering the market, further reducing supply.

ETH and other tokens are highly correlated to BTC. A lot of hedge funds trade ETH and other tokens against BTC instead of USD, to minimize FX risk.

So, if BTC goes up, it will have a secondary effect of increasing values of ETH and other tokens.

1. What was the most significant news in the cryptocurrency market for February?

In February, the cryptocurrency market witnessed notable bullish trends, primarily fueled by the successful launch of BTC ETFs, rapid advancements in Bitcoin layer 2 solutions, and the emergence of Bitcoin-based assets like Ordinals. This led to BTC's price escalation beyond $57k. A particularly noteworthy event was MicroStrategy's declaration of its focus on Bitcoin development, with Michael Saylor's strategy of BTC acquisition positioning it uniquely among large technology corporations.

2. What is anticipated to be the largest crypto news story in March?

For March, it is projected that the undervaluation of BTC relative to its potential market will capture significant attention. Described as "digital gold," BTC more accurately represents a new asset class on the brink of appreciation due to the April halving and ongoing demand from institutional and traditional finance sectors. This expected appreciation in BTC's price is likely to benefit ETH and the broader crypto ecosystem due to their strong price interdependence.

Alongside these price increases, there is an expectation for the introduction of innovative DeFi solutions that enable BTC holders to generate investment yield in a secure manner. Currently, yield generation options are limited to those requiring trust in centralized entities, making BTC holdings less capital efficient. The anticipation of new DeFi methodologies for BTC, especially through the use of Discreet Log Contracts, suggests a move towards trustless yield generation mechanisms.

Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
Certainly!

BTC ETF demand has surpassed even optimistic expectations from TradFi.

When I got into BTC full time in 2021, I made an intro for my friend, who ended up building the Chivo wallet for El Salvador. For me, that was the first signal that BTC had "crossed the chasm" - even non-technical family members could understand it, and benefit from it.

I always sensed the next shoe to drop would be Wall St, then Main St. We're at the Wall St stage. The ETF business is booming and large funds who skipped it first time (e.g. Morgan Stanley) also wants in now. Fidelity (Canada) now recommended holding up to 3% of investments in BTC.

Demand is high, but supply is very constrained. Satoshi isn't moving his genesis BTC. Saylor and Bukele bought up as much BTC as they could, and so did a lot of retail investors, following their lead. Many of these have held over multiple crypto boom and bust cycles. Lots of diamond hands. With the halving coming up, supply shock will exacerbate it more.

How high can it go? Some miners I've spoken to recently would sell part of their shares at $100k. I don't see a theoretical limit. Unlike altcoins, BTC doesn't have an emissions schedule - supply will be maxed at 21Mn.

Human minds are built for linear thinking - 1X, 2X. We struggle with exponentials/non-linearity. The market clearing price will rise until supply and demand meet. Given that the BTC PoW network is the single most powerful decentralized security infrastructure in the world, the price of security can be - quite high. Health, wealth and education know no max price.

Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
1. Can the price of Ethereum eventually reach $50,000?

Assuming USD inflation of 3% per year, Eth at $4,000 would eventually grow to Eth at $50,000 over 85 years. However, it is quite difficult to forecast that far into the future, as we could very well be running other blockchains by then.

To get a short-term price target for Eth, we need to first consider its utility. Although Eth was originally the smart contract layer of choice, it has transitioned to be more of a final state settlement layer for Eth L2s and sidechains.

Previously, all transactions happened on Eth directly. But gas fees spiked (often to hundreds of $ per transaction), which necessitated rollups such as Arbitrum, Polygon, etc. to be built.

When the user executes a transaction on an L2, some of the fees go to the L2 and some to Eth. This means that, as Eth scales via L2s, it will only capture some of each transaction‚Äôs value.

The industry is now scoping out L3s, to further lower fees and enable scalability via eventual consistency.

I do feel bullish about Eth, but I see $50k as unlikely to be attained.



2. Do you believe Ethereum will outperform Bitcoin in the long term? Why or why not?

I don‚Äôt think so.

Bitcoin has a supply cap of 21Mn, with no ability for further emissions. This creates a deflationary system that is one of the hallmarks of the token, and one of the reasons that miners have made massive capital investments to mine it.

Ethereum, on the other hand, has infinite max supply. The Ethereum foundation frequently adjusts its monetary policy and can adjust the emission schedule as needed.

The circulating supply of Eth is currently around 120Mn Eth, or nearly 6 times that of BTC. It is not feasible to imagine a world where one Eth token is worth more than one BTC.

Garreth Browne Wachsman

Ciara Smith Wachsman
Hi @akibalogh hope you‚Äôre doing well.

As you might already be aware, Ethereum‚Äôs Dencun upgrade to introduce proto-dank sharding has been in motion over the last few weeks. The upgrade was activated on all test networks on January 17th, including Goerli, Sepolia, and Hole≈°ky. The upgrade is scheduled for Wednesday, March, 13th, and is expected to significantly reduce layer 2 (L2) transaction fees and enhance Ethereum‚Äôs scalability, efficiency, and security. https://crypto.news/ethereums-dencun-upgrade-launch-march/

Would you have any insights, hot takes, or comments to share regarding these developments? It would be great for us to proactively pitch this out to reporters ahead of the upgrade on March 13th. Thank you!
üëç
GB
AB
07:28
Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
Thank you @ciarasmith1 ! I haven't been as close to EIP-4844, so I can't comment on the status of the tech itself.

But I can offer a hot take. 13 years ago, the NoSQL movement began, where the constraints of structured SQL data were opened up. Players like MongoDB emerged that let developers store any type of data in blobs.

Over the years, MongoDB became the tool of choice for developers, especially at startups, since it encouraged rapid prototyping, which then leads to adoption.

To me, EIP-4844 reads similarly. Giving developers large blobs of temporary data (i.e. deleted after 30 days) gives them the opportunity to innovate while not increasing load on the network. Storage is cheap anyway, whereas consensus network I/O is the bottleneck. Similar to Mongo's effect, this proposal will help innovation as Dapps and chains find new ways to use the temp storage space.

AB
10:46
Aki Balogh
- What does this partnership fully entail?

Amber Group is playing 3 roles:

1. They'll be our first dlcBTC merchant, meaning that they'll have access to the bridge and can mint/burn dlcBTC. They can then earn fees by trading it with other parties (e.g. exchanges, lending desks, hedge funds, etc.)

2. They are going to be our first market maker, so they'll stabilize the dlcBTC-BTC peg. They can also mint/burn dlcBTC to exploit arbitrage opportunities when the peg diverges

3. They're also our first end user, in the sense that they're using BTC on their balance sheet to mint dlcBTC. They'll provide some starting liquidity for our wBTC-dlcBTC pool on Curve
üëç
GB
10:46
- Amber Group has WhaleFin integrated, will dlcBTC will be listed on WhaleFin?

We haven't discussed this to date. Is WhaleFin a CEX? We'll be launching on MEXC first, then other exchanges later
üëç
GB
10:47
- You mentioned "exploring Amber Group's services (loans, investment products) through their use of a safer wrapped BTC", is this something that is also happening now or a longer-term plan?

It's a longer-term plan. Amber offers lending & investment products. In the future, they could potentially offer products that run on dlcBTC

Peter M ‚ôü Moricz PMM

Four ways BlackRock‚Äôs BUIDL tokenised fund on Ethereum will revolutionise markets:

Easy Connections:
BlackRock's decision to launch a tokenised fund on Ethereum creates a bridge between traditional financial markets and the rapidly growing world of cryptocurrencies. This bridge allows for smoother interactions and transactions between the two, making it easier for large institutional investors to participate in blockchain-based financial products. By bringing together firms from both sides, such as traditional financial institutions like BNY Mellon and cryptocurrency platforms like Coinbase, BlackRock's fund fosters collaboration and interoperability in the market.

Saving Money:
Blockchain technology, which underpins Ethereum and similar platforms, offers several advantages that can translate into cost savings for investors. One major benefit is the ability to settle transactions almost instantly, 24/7, without the need for intermediaries like banks. This not only reduces transaction costs but also minimizes the risk of errors and delays. Additionally, blockchain technology provides greater transparency, allowing investors to track their investments in real-time and ensuring that fees and charges are clear and fair.

Using a Popular Platform:
Ethereum is one of the most widely used and trusted blockchain platforms in the world. By choosing Ethereum for its tokenised fund, BlackRock gains access to a robust ecosystem with a wide range of tools and applications. Ethereum's popularity and network effects also mean that there are more opportunities for collaboration and innovation, such as integrating stablecoins (digital currencies pegged to stable assets like the US dollar) for transactions and exploring new types of investments beyond traditional assets like stocks and bonds.

Exciting New Opportunities:
The launch of BlackRock's tokenised fund on Ethereum represents a significant step forward in the evolution of financial markets. It signals a growing acceptance of blockchain technology and cryptocurrencies by mainstream financial institutions and opens up new possibilities for investors and asset managers alike. For investors, tokenised funds offer the potential for higher returns, increased liquidity, and greater diversification. For asset managers, they represent a new avenue for growth and innovation, with the opportunity to create novel investment products and tap into new markets. Overall, BlackRock's initiative is not just about one fund‚Äîit's about embracing a new paradigm in finance that promises to revolutionize the way we invest and manage assets.

06:47
Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
M&A is driven by consolidation, which happens when there are similar companies in a space that cover different markets, geographies, etc. Crypto has been an early industry and has boomed, resulting in a proliferation of similar protocols (DEXes, small chains, etc.). It‚Äôs quite normal that M&A would happen to consolidate them. M&A ends up pulling together a few winning companies that can dominate a market (think PepsiCo and Coca Cola, which run the soft drink, water and related markets).

There is nothing unique to crypto that would prevent M&A. Several years ago, Keep Network and NuCypher merged to create Threshold. One had a unique technology and the other had a node network, so they found a natural synergy. They worked out a program by which the tokens of each could be exchanged for a resulting Threshold token.

The liquidity and volatility of tokens mirror the dynamics of public company mergers, where setting token exchange rates is akin to determining share exchange ratios. This allows investors to assess the merger's value impact and bet for or against the merger happening.

Regulatory complexity is always a risk, since regulation has not been fully defined. However, it‚Äôs likely that many tokens would be treated equally under regulation, so a merger of two similar tokens could happen.

The next wave of M&A is likely to occur in sectors where there is a high degree of fragmentation, like Layer 1 chains that didn‚Äôt break Top 10, DEXes, DeFi protocols, node operators and possibly even NFT projects.

Garreth Browne Wachsman
Hi @akibalogh, I hope you are well. A journalist at Blockworks we reached out to with the embargo came back to us asking "how does dlcBTC compare to Babylon and Nomic implementations of similar ideas?"

From what we can see Babylon is a BTC staking platform - I know you were vocal in the past that there's no such thing as BTC staking. With Nomic I'm not too familiar but it looks like Nomic's bitcoin is not native. Would you be able to provide some clarity for us to get back to him with? If we can share some additional context and clarify dlcBTC's uniqueness they might be willing to accept the press release which would be great. Thank you
PM

AB
08:50
Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
Sure! Happy to give a high-level answer, and I can also get in deeper technical detail if needed.

Babylon - uses a unique mechanism to emulate covenants. But net-net, it functions like a bridge. The user locks BTC with a second outcome, determined by Babylon's systems, that can move the BTC to Babylon's side. If the system is hacked, there is a way to steal the BTC, or lose it thorough some manipulation of the slashing conditions. Whereas with dlcBTC, the BTC is programmatically guaranteed to only pay out to the original depositor.

Nomic is a bridged BTC implementation, where their servers secure the BTC. This is similar to other bridged BTC designs, like tBTC, etc. However, not your keys, not your Bitcoin. Our design is unique in that the only servers used are BTC and ETH (ARB).. no other layers, intermediaries, etc. The user self-wraps and doesn't send their BTC to any other party.
üî•

Hey @akibalogh and @PeterMM, I'm just got off the phone with Nick Oleskiw from Euopean Business Magazine in the UK. For context, European Business Magazine would be a T2/T3 outlet with about 46K unique monthly visitors (UVMs) mainly based within the UK. At the present moment, paid media would not be of benefit unless it was a unique opportunity with a major T1 outlet. Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
The appeal of a 24/7 market is clear, both to professional and retail traders and to the exchanges themselves. It makes sense to see the NYSE responding to competitive pressures from DeFi and crypto in general.

Will it influence NYSE to adopt blockchain and related technologies? Perhaps not directly. But I would argue, as NYSE and other TradFi exchanges analyze the innovative products that are being built on DeFi, they will understand that the competitive moat is widening.

A year ago, I held a presentation to AmEx's credit team on DeFi lending products. Over 50 people attended, including several AmEx executives. They were intrigued by the techniques that have been invented, even at such an early stage. Defi has only been around for 5 years, yet it's evolving rapidly.

I'll share the deck with you. By the way, only 1 person out of the 50 asked questions - seemed like only that one person really understood it. It was new information to everyone else.

1280√ó811, 142.4 KB
Hey Aki,

We are familiar with newswire services and will utilize them if requested by clients to increase coverage around announcements for the benefit of SEO, etc. While Chainwire might seem like a good option for news distribution, it is one of the more costly options. A lot of these services also claim to guarantee coverage with T1 outlets, which we know is never a certainty.

In comparison to Cision, Chainwire's prices are significantly higher with the risk of little return. On top of that, we have been successful in securing earned media with some of the outlets outlined below (e.g. Cointelegraph), so there's certainly no need to pay these prices in order to receive coverage (and the value/credibility of organic coverage will always outweigh that of paid media).

We're happy to connect with Chainwire on your behalf if needed but otherwise, we wouldn't recommend spending this kind of money for press release distribution. Thanks, Garreth
09:06
In comparison Cision charges approximately $350-$400 for distribution depending on the length of a release

Peter M ‚ôü Moricz PMM
In reply to this message
@garrethbrowne let me know what you think about this.


Yesterday's news about the odds of Spot ETH ETF approval surprised everyone. It would be one of the most significant political shifts in any administration regarding crypto. Last week's bipartisan Senate vote overturning the SEC's SAB 121 might have helped to change the sentiment towards quicker approval of Spot ETH ETF, but I'm not sure it will be May 23rd as people are expecting, but being approved is more "when and not if." Will Spot ETH ETF become a political agenda like BTC ETF? I don't think so, and it will get approved before the November election. When the Spot ETH ETF approval gets announced, "buy the rumor, sell the news" is precisely what I will do, but that doesn't mean I am bearish on ETH; rather, I take some profit off the table as any good trader would. The institutional money will flow slower to Spot ETH ETF than it did to BTC ETF because the Funds need to understand the demand for Spot ETH ETF. BTC ETF was in high demand and easily explained as "digital gold," hedge against inflation and global uncertainty. At the same time, ETH is more complicated to describe since many more use cases exist.

Hey Aki! Which protocol are you thinking? Or is it multiple protocols down the line? I think from your end, you could highlight that DLC.Link is integrated with/compatible with the relevant protocol (avoiding terms like in a "partnership with" or "collaborating with" to distance yourself from said protocol), without an explicit call to action. Beyond that, if you're trying to have it highlighted to users that dlcBTC can help them earn an APY through a defi protocol, it's probably just safest to have the protocol promote that themselves if they're open to co-marketing/having that kind of conversation to draw in more users.

Typically that's how we see these things promoted, particularly because there are a lot of decentralized projects that aren't in a position to promote themselves (so they leave it to the main company building on/marketing the protocol in question).

Whatever centralized entity is adjacent to the defi protocol will usually manage marketing for those things. Even with a disclaimer about risk & volatility, there's probably some invitation of regulatory scrutiny for DLC.Link when you direct users to a defi protocol. For the protocol itself, the centralized entity running alongside it will usually handle the regulatory compliance and that kind of stuff that comes with promotion, so it's a bit safer for them because they have a specialized team managing that (e.g. Uniswap Labs or Aave Labs/Avara)

07:46
Aki Balogh
Hi W team - following Babylon‚Äôs $70Mn raise, I want to go live and highlight their weaknesses.

1. Monolithic system - complicated - prone to attacks and unforeseen risks. Esp when large amounts of money kept in a single mechanism. One bad commit can result in major losses

2. Complex design is not composable. Defi flourished by taking centralized banks and building out their components in a flexible way. Babylon might be first, but other protocols will take out their components piece by piece and create better implementations. This is the point of Defi.

3. Permissionless means that grey money can enter their system. It seems they cannot be compliant with institutions

4. Yields will likely be low, since there‚Äôs too much TVL securing too little security need. Eigen ran into this problem (more than 10X TVL compared to what was needed).

How best to promote competitive messaging?
4 June 2024

Ciara Smith Wachsman
In reply to this message
Hi Aki - Generally, it's best to avoid directing criticism toward competing projects or drawing attention to the weaknesses of a competitors product/project as this could be viewed as 'confrontational' within the media. Instead, we would advise that you point out the current gaps across existing wrapped bitcoin providers more generally (without specific reference to any project in particular) and pointing to how current solutions may not meet investor needs in the long run.

Then, you can juxtapose DLC.Link against this backdrop to emphasize how DLC.Link takes an innovative approach to wrapped bitcoin and offers investors long term security and reliable returns, with compliance at the forefront of all transactions. Generally, it's best to to focus on the positive rather than the negative, highlighting how DLC.Link addresses existing shortcomings in the market for wrapped bitcoin and brings value to the industry on the whole.

The key factor here is the new SEC chair, who, if less aggressive in enforcement around the crypto, could significantly impact the market in a positive way. The rest of the agencies who are supposed to monitor it will also play a role. The USA will become a more crypto-friendly jurisdiction to work in rather than walk away from, providing a sense of reassurance and confidence in the future of BTC.




2. Do you believe Bitcoin prices could eventually reach $1 million? If so, how and when? If not, why not?

BTC can reach $1 million because there have never been assets class in Traditional Finance (TradFi) where you know exactly how much you have. In BTC, you know, precisely, that is 21 million, while you don't know how much gold or oil is out there or how much stock will be offered or split later on. The scarcity of the BTC is real, and with 75% of the BTC being Hodled while mining is getting less and cost more, there is only a fine night that you can get your hands on. Miners needed to sell off their holdings to cover costs, which put on sell pressure, but now, with USA BTC ETF, they are buying everything up supply up, and before the rest of the world rolls out their own BTC ETF, demand will be even higher. Also, new technologies are rolling out, like DLC.Link where miners and BTC holders can hang onto their BTC and hedge it themselves rather than sell it or have their BTC earn Yields while sitting in their Wallets.
The timeline is trickier, but I would say BTC will hit $1 million in the next ten years.

Aki Balogh
In reply to this message
Hi W team - FYI - @trevorisonline is going to kick off a Twitter fight on this next week. Supported by the Nektar announcement on Tues and, next week, the ChorusOne podcast recording.

Main messages:

Security
- Babylon is not trustless. You have to trust their mechanism. BTC can be stolen through their slashing mechanism. They can't claim that it's theft-proof.
- We are also not trustless ‚Äî our attestors could collude. But we are 100% theft-proof. The BTC can only go back to the original depositor. This is called "trust-minimized"

Composability
- Babylon's founder David Tse often makes the point that the more complex a system is, the more attack vectors it has. Yet, they've launched a new chain, new staking ecosystem, etc. It's very monolithic.
- Instead, we leverage composability. We make the self-wrapping mechanism that makes BTC liquid. Then dlcBTC goes on any chain, into any type of vault and yield protocol. We believe that this is a faster, safer approach since it uses tried-and-true methods vs. reinventing the wheel.

To deliver Bitcoin staking, we use time-tested protocols, avoiding reliance on Babylon, Bitcoin L2s (sidechains) or other untested technologies with risks that are not yet fully understood.

Secure your Bitcoin with theft-proof Discreet Log Contracts (DLCs) on Bitcoin L1, ensuring optimal control and security.
